summary: Email correspondence between attorneys regarding requests for disclosure in the criminal case United States v. Jeffrey Epstein (19-CRIM-00490) following Epstein's death. The email chain involves attorneys from Steptoe & Johnson LLP and the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York discussing procedural matters and indicating that no further productions will be made in the criminal case due to Epstein's death and anticipated nolle prosequi.

events.title: Civil Division email regarding disclosure
events.description: Email sent by the Civil Division of the US Attorney's Office regarding disclosure requests in the Epstein case.

events.title: Disclosure requests submitted
events.description: Michael Miller submits disclosure requests pursuant to DOJ Touhy regulations regarding the Epstein case.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The document references Epstein's death as reason for halting further productions in the criminal case.

events.title: Anticipated nolle prosequi order
events.description: The US Attorney's Office anticipates entry of a nolle prosequi order (declination to prosecute) following Epstein's death.

locations: 1114 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10036
keyFacts: The document confirms that following Jeffrey Epstein's death, the US Attorney's Office stated 'no further productions will be made in the context of the criminal case'.
The correspondence references anticipated entry of a nolle prosequi order (declination to prosecute) due to Epstein's death.
Attorneys from Steptoe & Johnson LLP were seeking disclosure requests pursuant to DOJ Touhy regulations regarding the Epstein case.
The email chain shows coordination between defense attorneys and the US Attorney's Office regarding procedural matters post-Epstein's death.
The document indicates separate service of requests was planned for the MCC (Metropolitan Correctional Center) and FBI if the US Attorney's Office wouldn't accept service.
